message.content: We refer to the image and Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The image shows black necrotic eschars in the nasal mucosa, which is highly suggestive of rhinocerebral mucormycosis, caused by Rhizopus infection. The patient's poorly controlled diabetes may have contributed to this opportunistic infection. None of the other options are consistent with the findings in the image.

We can see in figure A that there is black necrotic tissue on the nasal septum. This is a hallmark finding of mucormycosis, which is caused by fungus in the order Mucorales, including the Rhizopus species. Therefore, (C) Rhizopus infection is the correct answer. Cryptococcal and Candida infections typically do not present with necrotic tissue, and gram negative bacterial infections do not typically cause mucormycosis.

We refer to the image provided in the question and to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The image shows nasal mucormycosis, which is caused by the fungus Rhizopus. Cryptococcal and Candida infections do not typically present with this type of tissue necrosis. Gram negative bacterial infections may lead to tissue necrosis but do not typically present with the classic black eschar seen in mucormycosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The figure shows black eschars forming on the nasal turbinates, a classic sign of invasive fungal sinusitis caused by Rhizopus. Cryptococcal and Candida infections can also cause nasal symptoms but do not usually cause the characteristic black eschars. Gram-negative bacterial infections typically do not cause nasal eschars.

We refer to the image shown in figure A and to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The image shows black, necrotic material in the nasal cavity, which is characteristic of Rhizopus infection. The patient's poorly controlled diabetes puts her at increased risk for fungal infections, including Rhizopus. Cryptococcal and Candida infections are less likely to present with this specific type of necrotic tissue, and a gram-negative bacterial infection would not typically present with this type of tissue at all.
